author: Mark Langshaw
title: Hackers breach T-Mobile partner and steal data on 15 million customers - Tech
text: T-Mobile is the latest company to be targeted by hackers, as the operator's credit partner Experian has been breached and user data stolen.The incident has put anyone who has ever applied for device financing or service with the company in the last two years at risk, which is up to 15 million people. © Getty Images Experian has assured customers that no banking information was stolen in the breach, but personal data like names, addresses, birth dates and driver's licence and passport numbers was.T-Mobile has warned that the hackers may have broken Experian's encryption protection, but is offering affected customers two years of free credit monitoring.Ironically, this free credit monitoring is with Experian, although T-Mobile chief executive John Legere said on Twitter that alternatives are being looked into.One of our vendors, Experian, experienced a data breach. See what we're doing about it: https://t.co/1oTcclmGXe— John Legere (@JohnLegere) October 1, 2015Legere said that he was "incredibly angry about this data breach", but added that helping affected customers is his "top concern".The attack dates back to September 2013, but went undetected for two years.
